tags.documentation:
Availability = Actual Production Time / Potential Production Time

Example:
    A machine is scheduled to run for a full 8 hour shift (Potential Production time)
    with 2 planned 15 minute maintenance stops (Planned Stops)
    and 45 minutes of downtime due to machine failure (Unplanned Stops)

Actual Production Time  = Potential Production Time - Planned Stops - Unplanned Stops

    480 minutes - 30 minutes - 45 minutes = 405 minutes Actual Production Time

Availabilty = 405/480 = 0.84375 = 84.375 %
tags.tooltip: Availability = Actual Production Time / Potential Production Time
tags.name: Availability

tags.documentation:
OEE = Availabilty * Performance * Quality

The "Target Score" for OEE is around 85% which is a 95% score in Availabilty, Performance, and Quality.
A more realistic target is between 60 and 70%. 

Example:
    A machine runs for 405 minutes out of a possible 480 (84.375% Availabilty)
    It produces 245 units out of a possible 270 for the 405 minutes (90.74% Performance)
    222 of those 245 units are of good quality (90.612% Quality)

OEE = 0.84375 * 0.90740 * 0.90612 = 0.69374 = 69.374%
tags.name: OEE

tags.documentation:
Performance = Actual Output / Theoretical Output

Example:
    A machine is scheduled to run for a full 8 hour shift (480 minutes) but has an Actual Production Time of 405 minutes.
    This machine has an Ideal Cycle Time of 1.5 minutes, but during the Actual Production Time, the machine produced 245 units.

Theoretical Output = Actual Production Time / Ideal Cycle Time

    405 minutes / 1.5 minutes = 270 units Theoretical Output

Performance =  245/270 = 0.90740 = 90.74%
tags.name: Performance

tags.documentation:
Quality = Good Unit Output / Actual Unit Output

Example:
A machine produces 245 units during a shift, but 13 of these are declared as rejected units, so there are 222 good units.

Quality = 222 / 245 = 0.90612 = 90.612 %
tags.tooltip: Quality = Good Unit Output / Actual Unit Output
tags.name: Quality
